item.title: Conservative rebels to force vote on reversing aid cuts
item.description: The MPs believe they have enough support to bring the 0.7% of national income commitment back into law.

item.title: Israel opposition parties agree to form new unity government
item.description: Naftali Bennett will initially become PM, meaning an end to Benjamin Netanyahu's 12-year tenure.

item.title: School catch-up tsar resigns over lack of funding
item.description: England's school recovery commissioner Sir Kevan Collins quits, saying the funding "falls far short".

item.title: Covid-19: Lack of queue-jumping helped vaccine drive, says Matt Hancock
item.description: The health secretary says the "fair" rollout of Covid vaccines was critical to winning public trust.

item.title: Princess Diana's wedding dress going on display at Kensington Palace
item.description: The gown has been loaned to the exhibition by her sons Prince William and Prince Harry.

item.title: UK records hottest day of the year for third day in row
item.description: Temperatures reached as high as 28.3C in London on Wednesday afternoon.

item.title: Donald Trump's 'communications' platform permanently taken offline
item.description: The former US president will return to social media, an aide says - but exactly how remains unclear.

item.title: Working from home: Call to ban out-of-hours emails from bosses
item.description: The UK government is urged to bring in a French-style law giving workers "the right to disconnect".

item.title: Petrol prices at highest in two years, says RAC
item.description: Fuel prices are climbing as economies reopen and energy prices soar.

item.title: Dea-John Reid racially abused before Kingstanding stabbing, say police
item.description: Dea-John Reid, 14, was described by his family as an "incredibly talented young boy".

item.title: Sri Lanka: Chemical-filled X-Press Pearl ship threatens marine life and beaches
item.description: Officials failed to tow the X-Press Pearl into deeper water, in an effort to limit the environmental impact.

item.title: England cricketer apologises for racist tweets
item.description: England seamer Ollie Robinson apologises after historical tweets of a racist and sexist nature are revealed during his Test debut.

item.title: The Papers: Children 'let down' and holidays 'under threat'
item.description: The front pages lead with reaction to school catch-up plans and warnings over Covid's potential impact on travel abroad.

item.title: Huge caterpillar web blankets Yorkshire hedgerow
item.description: The web in South Yorkshire is described by one expert as a "very impressive infestation".

item.title: 'Sea snot' spreads across Turkish sea
item.description: A thick layer of sea snot is spreading in Turkey’s Sea of Marmara to the south of Istanbul.

item.title: Malala on Vogue cover: ‘I know power in a young girl’s heart’
item.description: Appearing on the cover of British Vogue, the 23-year-old reflects on her activism and university life.

item.title: Blue Abyss: Plans to build world's deepest pool in Cornwall
item.description: The £150m project to build a 50m deep pool would be used for deep sea and space research.

item.title: Two children, a decade of war in Syria
item.description: BBC correspondent Caroline Hawley revisits two refugee children who symbolise the suffering inflicted by Syria's war.

item.title: Ai Weiwei's Gilded Cage unveiled at Blenheim Palace
item.description: The golden structure over seven metres tall will go long-term view at the world heritage site.

item.title: Why is it harder to diagnose disorders on non-white skin?
item.description: Kanayo Dike-Oduah was sent home from A&E twice while suffering from a rare but serious illness.

item.title: Why students in South Africa are turning to food banks
item.description: South African students like Bianca Nonhlanhla Skhosana are increasingly using food banks to survive.

item.title: Blocking traffic as a human bollard
item.description: Why some residents in Oxford have taken traffic congestion into their own hands.

item.title: Emma Coronel Aispuro: The rise and fall of a drug kingpin’s wife
item.description: El Chapo's wife led a life of glamour in New York until her arrest on drug trafficking charges.

item.title: Pension scandal: 'I've lost 14 years of payments'
item.description: Tens of thousands of elderly female pensioners are set to miss out on life changing payments.

item.title: Why house prices are rising so fast in a pandemic
item.description: House prices are increasing at their fastest rate for more than a decade. These graphics explain why.

item.title: Sir Keir Starmer: Five things we learned from Piers Morgan interview
item.description: We look at what the Labour leader revealed in his interview on ITV's Piers Morgan's Life Stories.

item.title: Covid: The Australian millennials desperate for vaccines
item.description: Locked out of a troubled vaccination scheme, young people are increasingly desperate to get jabbed.

item.title: Pakistani intelligence accused of torture in crackdown on dissent
item.description: Pakistan's intelligence service accused of kidnap and torture in crackdown on dissenting voices.

item.title: The city dwellers who want a more tribal way of living
item.description: A group of Edinburgh residents want to buy a 19th Century mansion to create their own community.

item.title: Farmers' opposition to UK-Australia trade deal grows
item.description: Opposition among UK farmers is rising towards the trade deal close to being concluded with Australia.

item.title: The 'kindness and propaganda' of a life in Belarus
item.description: From protests to exile, 22-year-old Maria tells Radio 1 Newsbeat what her home country is like.

item.title: What is the fallout from Osaka's withdrawal?
item.description: As Roland Garros loses one of the sport's biggest stars, the issues raised by Osaka's withdrawal sit firmly in the spotlight.

item.title: What students really want from school catch-up
item.description: Longer days? More tutors? Or stopping all the uncertainty? Pupils say what school recovery should mean.

item.title: England 1-0 Austria: Bukayo Saka seals win with first international goal
item.description: Bukayo Saka scores his first international goal as England warm up for Euro 2020 with a victory against Austria.

item.title: Netherlands 2-2 Scotland: Steve Clarke's side record creditable draw as Euros looms
item.description: A depleted Scotland begin their preparations for Euro 2020 in positive fashion despite Memphis Depay's late free-kick denying them victory over the Netherlands in Portugal.

item.title: Conway's debut century blunts England - highlights and report
item.description: Devon Conway's superb unbeaten 136 on Test debut helps New Zealand to 246-3 against England on the opening day of the first Test at Lord's.

item.title: France 3-0 Wales: Neco Williams sent off in pre-Euro 2020 friendly
item.description: Neco Williams is shown a first-half red card as Wales are beaten 3-0 by France in their pre-Euro 2020 friendly in Nice.

item.title: Williams 'happy to get through' battle with Buzarnescu
item.description: Serena Williams moves into the French Open third round after overcoming Romania's Mihaela Buzarnescu in a three-set battle.

item.title: England v New Zealand: Conway hits century on Test debut as New Zealand dominate on day one
item.description: Devon Conway hits an unbeaten 136 runs on his Test debut as New Zealand dominate day one of the first Test against England at Lord's.

item.title: Covid: What do under-30s need to know about the vaccine?
item.description: The vaccine rollout is now reaching younger adults. What do they need to know about getting jabbed?

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: How is Europe lifting lockdown restrictions?
item.description: A third Covid wave hit much of Europe hard but now gradually lockdowns are being eased.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Tokyo Olympic Games: When are they and will they go ahead despite Covid?
item.description: The Tokyo Summer Olympics are due to start in July, despite a surge in Covid cases in Japan.

item.title: What are the rules for travelling to green, amber and red list countries?
item.description: Foreign holidays are now possible, but travellers must follow strict rules on their return.

item.title: Covid: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Scotland's Covid-19 rules are changing at the weekend - but for many, the lifting of lockdown has been "paused".

item.title: Covid: Should I be working from home or going back to the office?
item.description: As lockdown restrictions ease gradually across the UK, what are the rules about returning to work?

item.title: Covid vaccine update: Those that work - and the others on the way
item.description: Covid vaccination campaigns are under way in the UK and across the world.

item.title: Lockdown muscle loss: Five ways to get back in shape
item.description: Lockdown inactivity may have left people with weaker muscles - there are simple solutions.

item.title: Coronavirus: What's the risk of Covid on public transport?
item.description: As UK coronavirus restrictions are relaxed, public transport could become much busier.

item.title: Travel guide to Spain, Portugal, France and more holiday hotspots
item.description: What you need to know about travelling abroad to Portugal, Spain, Greece, France, Italy and Turkey.

item.title: How are eviction rules for renters and landlords changing?
item.description: The eviction ban is ending, but what does that mean?

item.title: The Motherload: How pandemic anger almost destroyed a mums' support group
item.description: Abusive messages from angry mums during lockdown almost caused the founder of The Motherload to close it down.

item.title: The children selling explicit videos on OnlyFans
item.description: British subscription site OnlyFans is failing to prevent underage users from selling and appearing in explicit videos, a BBC investigation has found.

item.title: How Ben Crump became America's go-to police brutality lawyer
item.description: When families lose a loved one in a police shooting, more often than not Ben Crump gets a call. Why is he the go-to man?

item.title: Samantha Azzopardi: Australia's notorious con artist sentenced for child theft
item.description: Authorities are baffled by the "bizarre crime" of a serial con artist who has travelled the world.

item.title: After a 32-year battle for justice, what is Hillsborough's legacy?
item.description: As the collapse of the last criminal trial marks the end of a long legal road, Judith Moritz asks what the legacy of Britain’s worst sports disaster is.
